intro: Pariana caxiuanensis, commonly known as the Brazilian starfruit, is a flowering plant native to the Atlantic rainforests of Brazil. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its striking, palmate leaves and showy, yellow-orange flowers. The plant produces small, edible fruits that are often consumed fresh or used in local cuisines. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is adapted to the nutrient-rich soils of its native habitat. Due to habitat loss, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
